response.answer_text: How can WhatsApp be hacked and what to do to avoid it Cybercriminals can use different techniques to steal access to your WhatsApp account. And once they do, in addition to being unable to use your profile, the information you have stored on that platform, such as your conversations, could fall into other hands. One of the ways that this can happen is that a cybercriminal, who knows your WhatsApp number, seeks to verify that account on another device. Of course, if you do, that account will no longer be available on your cell phone. But for this to happen, the system asks for a verification code that arrives by SMS or voice call. And if you received a message like that, you would realize that there is something strange but it could happen that the user who seeks to hack your account, when requesting to log in to your WhatsApp on his cell phone, asks to receive the code by voice and if you do not answer that call with the code, it will be recorded in the answering machine. “If it is requested that the message arrives by voice message and the user (the true owner of the account) does not answer because he is at the cinema or sleeping, for example, the code will be saved in the answering machine of his mobile. And in many cases, the password to access the voice answering machine that is by default is very easy to deduce. So if the user did not modify this password, the attacker could easily access the verification code in order to log into WhatsApp from his smartphone, "explained Luis Lubeck, Eset's security analyst, in dialogue with Infobae. It should be remembered that it is possible to access the cell phone answering machine from a landline telephone, hence an attacker can easily resort to this technique. Once the answering machine is entered in this way, you will be asked for the password to the answering machine which, as already mentioned, if it was not modified and is the one that is by default, is easily identifiable. In other cases, criminals use other methods, based on deception and other forms of social engineering, to get the account owner to inadvertently provide the verification code. "In some cases, an SMS is sent through a user contact who has previously been hacked with a message that says, for example: 'You received a code by mistake on your cell phone but in reality, it is for me, can you give please? ´. As you get the message from an acquaintance, you trust and give him the code, without thinking, ”Lubeck emphasizes. Once the attacker managed, by whatever method, to take control of the WhatsApp account, activating the second authentication factor to shield the account and regain access becomes very difficult. To make a claim of this type you have to contact the platform directly and verify the identity and that what one says is true is quite complex.  Here, the recommended precautionary measures recommended avoiding falling into these types of traps: 1. Activate the two-step verification by entering WhatsApp in the “Account” section, located within the “Settings” or “Configuration” section -depending on the device model. 2. If you receive a message that provides a verification code, avoid sharing it with third parties by any means. It does not matter if a supposed friend or acquaintance requests it: everything can be a hoax. 3. Remember that the platform does not ask its users for information through messages -SMS, WhatsApp, or other messaging services- or through phone calls. 4. If you receive a WhatsApp message from an unknown user, it is advisable to block and report the user through the options that will appear on the screen. 5. Check regularly on which devices WhatsApp Web sessions are open, and avoid opening sessions on shared devices. 6. In case of being the victim of a maneuver of this type, notify your contacts and report what happened before the corresponding authorities.

Everything is hackable. If human brain can create something then it can also hack it. But the question is always asked wrong, it's not about if something hackable or not, its about whether it's feasible to hack it or not. It all boils down to the benefit to time ratio. If you benefit too little by spending too much time and resource to achieve it, then there is no practical sense to hack. Every security measure that is designed right for any system, always depends on this key feature. Make it non feasible to break into the system. I will put forth a very practical example, people say that MAC’s are very safe and don't need antiviruses as they don't get infected. Do you think the brilliant hackers/ programmers out there are so incompetent to not hack into the system. No that is not the case, the point is MAC’s are less vulnerable partly because they are less used in comparison to a Win box, hence a hacker with malafide intentions would gain much more return on his investment of time by creating a malware for WIN. Even if he writes amazing code or finds a real tricky bug in MAC OS, his work won't pay dividend to him as the machine installed with MAC OS is very less comapred to WIN, and thus his intended target audience decreases and so does his potential scale of harm.

We have not developed a sharper eyesight, a more sensitive olfactory system, a more powerful muscular apparatus, and so on. As a matter of fact, our physical faculties are in general less advanced than those of our animal relatives, so it was not an improvement of the primary modelling system that explains our increased brain volume. It is highly likely, therefore, that the brain increase that took place in human evolution was largely due to the development of those new faculties that collectively make up our second modelling system, the system that eventually gave origin to language. The main point is that this new system was a genuine novelty, something that no other species managed to evolve. We are facing therefore the same problem that we encounter in all great events of macroevolution: how did living systems give origin to real novelties? A useful clue comes from another macroevolutionary event: the origin of the first animals. In that case the starting point was a population of cells that could assemble themselves in countless different ways, so how did they manage to generate those particular three-dimensional structures that we call animals?
